title: 113_hr3
content: The Act may be cited as the "Northern Route Approval Act". The Congress finds that investing in the Nation's infrastructure is crucial for economic competitiveness and long-term benefits. The delivery of oil from Canada through the Keystone XL pipeline is in the national interest to reduce dependence on foreign sources and create employment opportunities. The State of Nebraska has approved the Keystone XL pipeline reroute after considering Nebraskans' concerns and finding minimal environmental impacts. The Department of State and Federal agencies conducted extensive studies on the pipeline's technical, environmental, social, and economic impacts, concluding that it will not affect crude oil production from the oil sands. The Department of State found that the Keystone XL project will have minimal impact on crude oil production from the oil sands and will result in a small increase in greenhouse gas emissions. The Department of State found that the Keystone XL pipeline project would have no significant impacts on land and water resources along its proposed route. The transportation of oil via pipeline is deemed the safest and most effective method, with a strong safety and environmental protection record. The Department of State determined that the Keystone XL pipeline would have minimal environmental impact and high safety standards, similar to the Alaska Pipeline in 1973 before congressional action. The Federal regulatory process remains a significant obstacle to a project aimed at reducing oil imports from insecure foreign sources, similar to the Alaska Pipeline in 1973 before congressional action. The Federal regulatory process is a significant obstacle to reducing oil imports from insecure foreign sources, similar to the Alaska Pipeline in 1973 before congressional action. Keystone XL permit approval is addressed in Section 3. No Presidential permit is required for the Keystone XL pipeline as per the application filed by TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. The final environmental impact statement and the Nebraska reroute evaluation satisfy all necessary requirements. SEC. 4. JUDICIAL REVIEW. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has exclusive jurisdiction to determine the validity of final orders or actions of Federal agencies regarding the Keystone XL pipeline, the constitutionality of provisions in the Act, and the adequacy of environmental impact statements. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has exclusive jurisdiction over final orders or actions of Federal agencies regarding the Keystone XL pipeline, the constitutionality of Act provisions, and environmental impact statement adequacy. Claims under this Act must be filed within 60 days of the decision. The Court will expedite consideration, prioritizing national energy security and access to Canadian oil reserves. SEC. 5. AMERICAN BURYING BEETLE. The Congress finds that environmental reviews for the Keystone XL pipeline project meet Endangered Species Act requirements and will not harm the American burying beetle or its habitat. The Secretary of the Interior is deemed to have issued a statement under the Act regarding the project's impact on the beetle. The operation and maintenance of the Keystone XL pipeline, as defined in its entirety, is not considered a prohibited taking of endangered species under the Endangered Species Act. The Secretary of the Interior is deemed to have granted a right-of-way and temporary use permit for the Keystone XL pipeline under specific acts. Additionally, permits for activities in navigable waters are addressed. The Secretary of the Army must issue permits for the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline within 90 days of receiving the application. The Secretary has the authority to waive procedural requirements if necessary. If the Secretary does not take action, permits will be issued. If the Secretary does not issue a permit for the Keystone XL pipeline within 90 days, it will be deemed issued under specific laws. The Environmental Protection Agency cannot restrict activities authorized under this permit. The Secretary of the Interior is deemed to have issued a special purpose permit under the Migratory Bird Treaty Act for the Keystone XL pipeline. Pipeline owners must disclose oil spill response plans to State Governors for emergency preparedness. Updates to the plan must be provided within 7 days. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 22, 2013. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
